title: Google Nexus 8 still en route, despite I/O silence | Trusted Reviews
description:
![Nexus](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

**The[Google Nexus 8](https://www.trustedreviews.com/nexus-9-review) is still
en route for launch, despite not being officially introduced at the annual
Google I/O developers’ conference. **

Google announced a host of new software, including Android L and Android TV
among a slew of other smaller announcements, but failed to announce any new
hardware.

It was predicted that Google would announce the Nexus 8 as a successor or
upgrade to the Google Nexus 7 2, or even refresh the [Google Nexus
10](https://www.trustedreviews.com/google-nexus-10_Tablet_review), but sadly
there were no tablets to be seen.

However, according to a [CNET](http://www.cnet.com/uk/news/nexus-8-a-no-show-
at-google-io-still-on-its-way/) source that claims to be “familiar with the
device”, the Nexus 8 is still coming to market and was actually never due to
be on the Google I/O agenda.

The actual launch timings though are still to be confirmed it seems.

Rumour has it that the Nexus 8 will be built by HTC, rather that Asus who
manufacturers the Nexus 7. The Nexus 8, which no doubt would prove popular
with consumers as the Nexus line always has, would be a great support for HTC
too.

The Taiwanese company has really streamlined its product range in recent
years, relying on flagships like the [HTC One
M8](https://www.trustedreviews.com/htc-one-m8_Mobile-Phone_review) and mid-
range handsets like the [HTC One mini 2](https://www.trustedreviews.com/htc-
one-mini-2_Mobile-Phone_review).

echo-3607478 "Alexa’s new whisper mode rolls out in US today – here’s how to
enable it")

  * 

There have been a few rumours teasing the potential specs sheet of the Nexus
8, which is apparently going under the code name Flounder.

The latest suggests that the Nexus 8 display will be a 8.9-inch panel with a
2560 x 1600p QHD resolution, putting it on par with the Nexus 10, but with a
better pixel density.

As for the processing power, the Nexus 8 is expected to pack a 64-bit Tegra
CPU. This would line it up with the 64-bit Apple A7 processor found in the
[iPad Mini 2 Retina](https://www.trustedreviews.com/ipad-
mini-2-retina_Tablet_review).

Google did make a particular point in saying that its new Android L operating
system is compatible with 64-bit processors, so watch this space.

tablets_round-up)**
